00:24:50.590 --> 00:24:53.170

00:24:53.170 --> 00:24:56.765

00:24:56.765 --> 00:24:59.438

00:25:01.188 --> 00:25:04.112

00:25:07.617 --> 00:25:11.310

00:25:11.310 --> 00:25:15.200

00:25:15.200 --> 00:25:17.440

00:25:17.440 --> 00:25:20.330

00:25:20.330 --> 00:25:23.690

00:25:23.690 --> 00:25:26.740

00:25:26.740 --> 00:25:29.700
The network address translation here too.

00:25:29.700 --> 00:25:32.890
That's the default and

00:25:32.890 --> 00:25:38.290

00:25:38.290 --> 00:25:43.750

00:25:43.750 --> 00:25:47.490

00:25:47.490 --> 00:25:49.420

00:26:17.120 --> 00:26:21.837

00:27:00.680 --> 00:27:02.110

00:27:02.110 --> 00:27:03.300
This will also what?

00:27:03.300 --> 00:27:05.140
Replicate that too, and

00:27:05.140 --> 00:27:09.520
then it will also be able to respond

00:27:09.520 --> 00:27:13.360
So those are actually the two that you

00:27:13.360 --> 00:27:16.030
A lot of times people go oh I don't need
to replicate it because that will just

00:27:16.030 --> 00:27:17.450
duplicate the addresses.

00:27:17.450 --> 00:27:18.470
That's not what it's doing.

00:27:18.470 --> 00:27:21.740
You need to do that If you want

00:27:21.740 --> 00:27:23.130
you'll not get an address.

00:27:23.130 --> 00:27:25.320
So you wanna make sure that you know that,

00:27:25.320 --> 00:27:30.430
The host only creates a virtual

00:27:36.170 --> 00:27:39.080

00:27:39.080 --> 00:27:41.900
the VM but on a separate network.

00:27:41.900 --> 00:27:46.164

00:27:46.164 --> 00:27:49.090

00:28:00.256 --> 00:28:04.573

00:28:17.578 --> 00:28:21.902

00:28:21.902 --> 00:28:25.660
Okay, so it's very important that you

00:28:25.660 --> 00:28:26.910
that as well.

VM to multiple networks at the same time.

00:28:50.870 --> 00:28:53.910

It says, if the hardware says, here's what

00:04:36.910 --> 00:04:39.862
well then inside of that
Oracle VirtualBox layer,

00:04:39.862 --> 00:04:43.110
it says, I would just mimic that up here.

00:04:43.110 --> 00:04:47.330
So that when the Widows OS says, I need it

00:04:47.330 --> 00:04:50.705
translate it into what they
actual real hardware's saying.

00:04:50.705 --> 00:04:53.710
It's ready right there in

00:04:53.710 --> 00:04:58.690
sending it directly along without any

But still where we tend to see this

It seems like an application,

>> Right, so when we take a look at

notice as I pull them a little bit closer,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike introduce Microsoft’s Hyper-V found in Windows Server 2012R2.   They discuss how the Hyper-V role installs as a Type I hypervisor.  Then Mike shows some of the different settings that we might want to consider customizing before creating a VM in Hyper-V.  Since most Type I Hypervisors are used in a production environment they mention that taking the time to make the customization is worth the time and effort to be more efficient later as we produce more VMs on Hyper-V.

episodes.description: n this episode, Ronnie and Mike talk about the setting and configurations that we must consider when building a Hyper-V VM for production use.  They show how to configure resource settings during the creation and talk about some of settings that may need to be created separately then selected in the given wizard. episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes continue their discussion on Kernel-based Virtual Machine or KVM. They look at how to set up network communication by creating a bridged network adapter. They show how to configure forwarding in IPTables for the KVM platform. They will also demonstrate how to use SELinux to implement mandatory access control for the directory that the virtual machines use.
